$a)$ First, we have to find out the coupon payment which we denote with $CP$, where we assume that the face value $F$ is $\$1,000$ and the coupon rate $CR$ is $3\%$

$$\begin{align*} CP&=F \times CR\\[7pt] &=1,000 \times 3\%\\[7pt] &=1,000 \times 0.03\\[7pt] &=\$30 \end{align*}$$
 

So, the coupon payment is $\boxed{\$30}$
â€‹

Now, we have to find out the yield to maturity semi-annually of pre tax cost by using the excel sheet which we denote with $YTM$, where the number of years $NPER$ $(30+27-3)$ is $54$, coupon payment $PMT$ is $30$, present value $PV$ $(1,000 \times 0.93)$ is $-\$930$ and the face value we assume $FV$ is $\$1,000$

$$\begin{align*}
 YTM&=RATE(NPER, PMT,PV,FV) \times 2\\[7pt]
 &=RATE(54, 30,-930,1000) \times 2\\[7pt] 
&=6.56\%
 \end{align*}$$

Therefore, the yield to maturity pre tax cost  is $\boxed{6.56\%}$

$b)$ second, we have to find out the after-tax cost of debt which we denote with $AC$, where the pre-tax cost $PT$ is $6.56\%$ and the tax rate $TR$ is  $22\%$

$$\begin{align*}
AC&=PT \times (1-TR)\\[7pt]&=6.56\% \times (1-22\%)\\[7pt]
&=0.0656\times (1-0.22)\\[7pt]
&=0.0656 \times0.78\\[7pt]
&=0.051\\[7pt]
&=5.1\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the after-tax cost of debt us $\boxed{5.1\%}$

$c)$ Since it is the actual cost that a corporation faces after deducting the tax components, the after-tax cost of debt is more important, because of the tax deduction or interest payment, the corporation benefits from a lower loan cost of debt.
